etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in John Lydgate (c1370–c1449), poet and prior of Hatfield Regis. From Anglo-Norman chauntploure, chanteplur, Middle French chanteplure, Middle French, French chantepleure mixture or alternation of joy and sorrow, any of various water vessels or conduits, e.g. a can for watering plants, a siphon from chanter to sing + pleurer to weep

definitions: A mixture or alternation of joy and sorrow, especially as a literary image or device. rare after 16th century.

notes.text: Now only with reference to medieval literature.

definitions: A type of medieval watering pot, in the form of a (long-necked) earthenware jug with holes in the bottom, formerly sometimes used as a badge or heraldic device indicative of sorrow.

notes.text: The chantepleure was immersed in water to fill it, then the thumb placed over the neck hole, keeping the water in by means of suction. When the thumb was removed, the water flowed out through the holes in the bottom.
